awd_abstract_narration:
The share of the world’s population in extreme poverty declined from 43% in 1981 to 36% in 1990 to 10% in 2015, representing one of humanity’s great successes. Despite this success, the process by which poverty reduction takes place in nations is not well understood.  This research project will use a large data set and innovative methods to study how this reduction in poverty happened: what changed across generations and within the lives of individual households as they moved out of poverty.  The researchers do this systematically by using detailed household survey data from countries that collectively accounted for up to 85% of global poverty reduction since 1990. The project aims to advance understanding of the forces that give rise to shared prosperity, as well as contribute to scientific literacy about poverty’s decline and to graduate training in economics.  The results of this research will provide important inputs into the design of policies to reduce poverty in the US and across the globe.  It will also establish the US as the global leader in poverty reduction research.

Understanding the mechanisms through which poverty decreases is important in crafting policies to reduce poverty.  This research project will use household-  and  individual-level data  from many countries to systematically describe and study the forces behind the global fall of extreme poverty since circa 1990.   The research will examine  what  accounts  for  changes  in  households’  earnings  as  they  exit  from  (and  enter into) extreme poverty,  considering the roles of structural change,  occupational choice,  the division  of  labor,  and  gendered  participation  in  labor  markets,  among  other  factors.   This research will also examine the importance of these within-generation changes in aggregate poverty decline, relative to between-generation dynamics, as older, poorer generations are replaced by younger, less-poor ones.  The research will use nationally and near-nationally representative longitudinal and repeated cross-section datasets from countries that collectively account for as much as 85% of the global reduction in extreme poverty since 1990.  The results of this research will provide important inputs into the design of policies to reduce poverty in the US and across the globe.  It will also establish the US as the global leader in poverty reduction research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The "How Poverty Falls" project describes the household- and cohort-level mechanics by which extreme poverty has fallen across the globe. It seeks to establish a set of facts about poverty decline that complement two approaches in growth and development economics. The first descriptively accounts for growth and prosperity at the macroeconomic level, while the second isolates the effects of policies or conditions that are relevant to the lives of poor people. The first approach’s focus on aggregates misses the trajectories of individual households living in or near extreme poverty, while the second approach’s focus on specific causal effects diverts attention from documenting broad facts about the process of poverty decline. Our project fills these gaps in a systematic way for five large countries that account for 40% of the global population and 70% of global poverty decline since 1990: China, India, Indonesia, Mexico, and South Africa. The Intellectual Merit of the project is to carry out this fact-finding mission in a harmonized way across multiple countries. The Broader Impact is to establish a common set of facts that will guide future research on poverty and shape both academic and non-academic conversations about poverty.

The project’s core data contribution is our compilation of data from two types of surveys fielded in these countries since circa 1990, one taking repeated snapshots of the population over time, the other following the same group of households over time. Combined, we harmonized 78 distinct rounds of data collection, each representing either the national population or a large subpopulation. These data allowed us to ask two broad questions about how poverty fell, which comprise the project’s core conceptual contribution. First, to what extent did it fall within generations, as opposed to between them? Second, did any key set of factors change in the economic lives of households as they transitioned out of (and into) poverty?

On the first question, the repeated snapshots of the population show that poverty fell over the lives of all living generations in parallel in parallel, so that poverty decline can be viewed as a primarily within-generation phenomenon. At any given point in time, the young and old exhibited similar poverty rates, which also implies that changes in the age structure of the population cannot account for a meaningful amount of poverty decline. On the second question, the longitudinal profiles of households’ lives show that no one pathway out of poverty predominated: households that changed sector, occupational status, women’s labor force participation, and so on did not primarily account for poverty exit. Furthermore, individual households’ progress out of poverty was substantial but not irreversible, with substantial churn in and out. Overall, the data suggest that no single theory of poverty can describe its retreat: not changes in human resources across generations, nor changes in labor arrangements, sectoral affiliation, labor force participation, or migration within generations. Poverty decline over recent history took diverse paths, and researchers seeking policies and programs to accelerate it should put their findings in this broader context. We have presented these results in several academic seminars and have completed a paper summarizing them, which we submitted to a major conference and will soon submit to a top economics journal.
